member.name: BY_HANDLE_FILE_INFORMATION
member.summary: Contains information that the function retrieves.

member.name: BY_HANDLE_FILE_INFORMATION.dwFileAttributes
member.summary: The file attributes. For possible values and their descriptions, seeFile Attribute Constants.

member.name: BY_HANDLE_FILE_INFORMATION.ftCreationTime
member.summary: A structure that specifies when a file or directory is created. If the underlying file system does not support creation time, this member is zero (0).

member.name: BY_HANDLE_FILE_INFORMATION.ftLastAccessTime
member.summary: A structure. For a file, the structure specifies the last time that a file is read from or written to. For a directory, the structure specifies when the directory is created. For both files and directories, the specified date is correct, but the time of day is always set to midnight. If the underlying file system does not support the last access time, this member is zero (0).

member.name: BY_HANDLE_FILE_INFORMATION.ftLastWriteTime
member.summary: A structure. For a file, the structure specifies the last time that a file is written to. For a directory, the structure specifies when the directory is created. If the underlying file system does not support the last write time, this member is zero (0).

member.name: BY_HANDLE_FILE_INFORMATION.dwVolumeSerialNumber
member.summary: The serial number of the volume that contains a file.

member.name: BY_HANDLE_FILE_INFORMATION.nFileSizeHigh
member.summary: The high-order part of the file size.

member.name: BY_HANDLE_FILE_INFORMATION.nFileSizeLow
member.summary: The low-order part of the file size.

member.name: BY_HANDLE_FILE_INFORMATION.nNumberOfLinks
member.summary: The number of links to this file. For the FAT file system this member is always 1. For the NTFS file system, it can be more than 1.

member.name: BY_HANDLE_FILE_INFORMATION.nFileIndexHigh
member.summary: The high-order part of a unique identifier that is associated with a file. For more information, seenFileIndexLow.

summary.para: The low-order part of a unique identifier that is associated with a file.

The identifier (low and high parts) and the volume serial number uniquely identify a file on a single computer. To determine whether two open handles represent the same file, combine the identifier and the volume serial number for each file and compare them.

The ReFS file system, introduced with Windows Server 2012, includes 128-bit file identifiers. To retrieve the 128-bit file identifier use the function with FileIdInfo to retrieve the structure. The 64-bit identifier in this structure is not guaranteed to be unique on ReFS.
